title: And/Or Press
text:
And/Or Press was an independent <a href="small%20press">small press</a> publisher based in the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Bay%20Area">San Francisco Bay Area</a> that operated from 1974 to 1983. The company published books on <a href="personal%20development">personal development</a>, guides to the <a href="countercultural">countercultural</a> lifestyle, and consciousness expansion. A number of the company's books were on the <a href="Psychedelic%20drug">psychedelic</a> experience and related subjects. And/Or Press was also one of the first book publishers to embrace <a href="underground%20comix">underground comix</a>, publishing collections by <a href="Bill%20Griffith">Bill Griffith</a>, <a href="Dave%20Sheridan%20%28cartoonist%29">Dave Sheridan</a>, and <a href="Fred%20Schrier">Fred Schrier</a>.
The company went out of business in 1983 after a hostile takeover; co-founder Joseph <a href="Sebastian%20Orfali">Sebastian Orfali</a> and his partner Beverly Potter immediately founded <a href="Ronin%20Publishing">Ronin Publishing</a>, which picked up the mantle And/Or Press had established. 
In 2009, the And/Or Press name was revived in <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>.
Overview.
A number of And/Or Press books on <a href="recreational%20drugs">recreational drugs</a> were high-volume sellers in the 1970s, including Mel Frank and Ed Rosenthal's "The Indoor Highest Quality Marijuana Grower's Guide", D. Gold's "Cannabis Alchemy", Adam Gottlieb's "Legal Highs", and <a href="Peter%20Stafford">Peter Stafford</a>'s "Psychedelics Encyclopedia". Edward Bauman, et al.'s "The Holistic Health Handbook" was a national bestseller. (And/Or Press published a number of books affiliated with the Berkeley Holistic Health Center.) The company republished <a href="Pitigrilli">Pitigrilli</a>'s 1933 book "Cocaine", as well as original works by <a href="Ernest%20Callenbach">Ernest Callenbach</a>, <a href="Paul%20Krassner">Paul Krassner</a>, <a href="Dennis%20McKenna">Dennis McKenna</a>, <a href="Jacques%20Vall%C3%A9e">Jacques Vallée</a>, and <a href="Robert%20Anton%20Wilson">Robert Anton Wilson</a>.
History.
And/Or Press was founded as a <a href="cooperative">cooperative</a> in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> by brothers Sebastian and John Orfali, Carlene Schnabel, and Charly Jenkewitz. (In 1973, Sebastian Orfali had owned People's Comix, a <a href="comic%20book%20retailer">comic book retailer</a> in San Francisco's <a href="North%20Beach%2C%20San%20Francisco">North Beach</a>). Among the first books the company published were Griffith and Kinney's "<a href="Young%20Lust%20%28comics%29">Young Lust</a> Reader", <a href="Pitigrilli">Pitigrilli</a>'s "Cocaine", and W. Golden Mortimer's "History of <a href="Coca">Coca</a>". Most of their catalog was sold through <a href="head%20shops">head shops</a> and other non-traditional venues.
By 1976 the company had moved to <a href="Berkeley%2C%20California">Berkeley, California</a>. By this time, the company was also acting as a distributor of other publishers' books on affiliated topics. And/Or Press incorporated in 1978. By 1980 the company had six employees and did about $1 million in business per year, mostly in traditional bookstores.
In 1982, And/Or Press joined with three other Bay Area presses to form Network, Inc., a publishing <a href="cooperative">cooperative</a> designed to help small presses compete with larger publishing houses. Orfali became Network, Inc.'s chairman. 
After the 1983 takeover of And/Or Press, Orfali and his long-time partner <a href="Beverly%20Potter">Beverly Potter</a>, PhD, formed <a href="Ronin%20Publishing">Ronin Publishing</a> under a similar mission as its predecessor. Many And/Or Press books were republished by Ronin Publishing. Orfali died in 1997 at age 51.
The And/Or Press name was revived in 2009 by a Vancouver, <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>-based publisher. The new And/Or Press has so far published a novel by <a href="Daryl%20Haney">Daryl Haney</a> ("<a href="Banned%20for%20Life">Banned for Life</a>", 2009) and a guide to the <a href="Maya%20Embedded%20Language">Maya Embedded Language</a> (Jana Germano's "Simplifying Maya", 2016).
